messages.title: LABOUR WILL BUILD AN NHS WITH THE TIME TO CARE
messages.content: Labour's pledge to recruit 20,000 more nurses, 8,000 more GPs, and ensure integrated, preventative health care with a single point of contact for those who need it. They also plan to balance the books without adopting the Conservatives' risky and extreme spending cuts.

keyPolicies.policyDescription: Labour pledges to recruit 20,000 more nurses, 8,000 more GPs, 3,000 more midwives, and 5,000 new home care workers. They propose binding waiting time guarantees and aim to put patients before profits by repealing privatisation plans, ensuring integrated preventative care, and balancing the books without extreme cuts.

issues.economy: Balance the books without adopting the Conservatives' risky and extreme plan to take spending as a share of national income back to levels of the 1930s.
issues.health: Recruit 20,000 more nurses, 8,000 more GPs, 3,000 more midwives, and 5,000 new home care workers, funded by a mansion tax on properties worth over £2 million, cracking down on tax avoidance and a levy on tobacco companies; introduce binding waiting time guarantees of GP appointments within 48 hours and cancer tests within one week; put patients before profits by appealing David Cameron's privatisation plans; and ensure an integrated, preventative 21st century national health and care service.

images.caption: A Labour campaign leaflet outlining the party's pledge for healthcare improvements.
